body:
### Describe the bug

The `__module__` of the type of a a cython-defined function ends up as a `member_descriptor` object rather than a string. This is a regression from Cython 3.0.12.


### Code to reproduce the behaviour:

```
$ uv pip install cython==3.1.0rc1
$ cat t.pyx
def foo(x):
  return x + 1
$ cythonize -b t.pyx
$ ipython
Python 3.13.2 (main, Feb 12 2025, 14:51:17) [Clang 19.1.6 ]
...

In [1]: import t
In [2]: type(t.foo).__module__
Out[2]: <member '__module__' of '_cython_3_1_0rc1.cython_function_or_method' objects>
In [3]: type(type(t.foo).__module__)
Out[3]: member_descriptor
```

### Expected behaviour

Under Cython 3.0.12, we see the following behavior, which seems more reasonable (`__module__` is a string):

```
$ uv pip install -U cython==3.0.12
$ cythonize -b t.pyx
...
$ ipython
In [1]: import t

In [2]: type(t.foo).__module__
Out[2]: '_cython_3_0_12'

In [3]: type(type(t.foo).__module__)
Out[3]: str
```

### OS

Linux

### Python version

3.13.2

### Cython version

3.1.0rc1

### Additional context

This appears to cause problems with mypy stubgen tool since it has difficulty parsing `__module__` on such functions.

comment_data.body:
This bisects to a2bd48d9e6ed02e56c8c9e2a962bb901d76a7c71.

I'll have a quick look, but it may be hard to fix.

Yeah - that's going to be hard to fix unfortunately. It looks like Python has different rules for `__module__` for heap-type and static types:

https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/1bc16504ef3866cc419f3781eef6528b93aee6b4/Objects/typeobject.c#L1451-L1473.
Why is `__module__` present in the `__dict__` as a descriptor object in the first place, though?
So that you get the right answer when you do `t.foo.__module__`
In principle that looks like it should work. We do let people replace the function's `__dict__` so we'd probably need a little care there to preserve `__module__` when they do that.

FWIW, this breaks at least parts of Dask, which relies on `type(x).__module__` in https://github.com/dask/dask/blob/ba63b71b6ae62fa814303b48bbe8bd9c5e081a69/dask/utils.py#L747. I'm trying to confirm just how much stuff breaks, but here's an example using `distributed.Client.submit`, which tokenizes the function:

```
import t  # from https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6841#issue-3039650288
from distributed import Client
client = Client(n_workers=1)
future = client.submit(t.foo, 1)
```

which fails with

```pytb
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[4], line 1
----> 1 future = client.submit(t.foo, 1)

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/distributed/client.py:2153, in Client.submit(self, func, key, workers, resources, retries, priority, fifo_timeout, allow_other_workers, actor, actors, pure, *args, **kwargs)
   2151 if key is None:
   2152     if pure:
-> 2153         key = funcname(func) + "-" + tokenize(func, kwargs, *args)
   2154     else:
   2155         key = funcname(func) + "-" + str(uuid.uuid4())

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dask/tokenize.py:76, in tokenize(ensure_deterministic, *args, **kwargs)
     74     token = _ENSURE_DETERMINISTIC.set(ensure_deterministic)
     75 try:
---> 76     return _tokenize(*args, **kwargs)
     77 finally:
     78     if token:

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dask/tokenize.py:34, in _tokenize(*args, **kwargs)
     33 def _tokenize(*args: object, **kwargs: object) -> str:
---> 34     token: object = _normalize_seq_func(args)
     35     if kwargs:
     36         token = token, _normalize_seq_func(sorted(kwargs.items()))

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dask/tokenize.py:154, in _normalize_seq_func(seq)
    152 _SEEN[id(seq)] = len(_SEEN), seq
    153 try:
--> 154     return tuple(map(_inner_normalize_token, seq))
    155 finally:
    156     del _SEEN[id(seq)]

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dask/tokenize.py:147, in _normalize_seq_func.<locals>._inner_normalize_token(item)
    145 if isinstance(item, _IDENTITY_DISPATCH):
    146     return item
--> 147 return normalize_token(item)

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dask/utils.py:771, in Dispatch.__call__(self, arg, *args, **kwargs)
    767 def __call__(self, arg, *args, **kwargs):
    768     """
    769     Call the corresponding method based on type of argument.
    770     """
--> 771     meth = self.dispatch(type(arg))
    772     return meth(arg, *args, **kwargs)

File /opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dask/utils.py:747, in Dispatch.dispatch(self, cls)
    744 lk = self._lookup
    745 for cls2 in cls.__mro__:
    746     # Is a lazy registration function present?
--> 747     toplevel, _, _ = cls2.__module__.partition(".")
    748     try:
    749         register = self._lazy[toplevel]

AttributeError: 'member_descriptor' object has no attribute 'partition'
```
I'm running into this too when passing my cython functions to dask and it checking for `type(x).__module__` as described in the above comment.

This does seem like something we do have to fix. The three options I can think of are: 

* The version proposed here that always instantiates the dict to store the `__module__` attribute. 
* My version involving overriding `__getattribute__` and `__setattr__` (needs a small fix for Py3.8 limited API)
* Something involving metaclasses (not yet worked out)
Your PR works well for my problem, for what it's worth.

I think we should probably try to fix this (and the related https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6897) in the next 3.1 release.

https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6882 is probably the better fix, but if we think it's too drastic then I could go back and fix up https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/6845 (which is a smaller change but does have a performance cost)

rename.from: [BUG] Invalid `method_descriptor` as __module__ on type(cython function) under 3.1.0rc1
rename.to: [BUG] Invalid `member_descriptor` as __module__ on type(cython function) under 3.1.0rc1

title: [BUG] Invalid `member_descriptor` as __module__ on type(cython function) under 3.1.0rc1
